newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.AFRICAN LUMBERJANES PLOT CHAINSAW MASSACRE.
newsitem.headline: S.AFRICAN LUMBERJANES PLOT CHAINSAW MASSACRE.

text.p: A dozen South African women are in training to become Green guerrillas in the battle against creeping insurgents -- alien trees that are sucking out the country's water.

The women are learning to use chainsaws and abseiling gear so they can be dropped by helicopter into inaccessible mountain catchment areas and chop down foreign trees like pines and wattles, a spokesman for the nature conservation department of the Western Cape province said.
Their five-week training course is part of a programme launched by Minister of Water Affairs and Forestry Kader Asmal whereby the unemployed can earn a small wage by chopping down unwanted trees.
The trees were originally imported to provide timber and other products but proliferated in the absence of the insects and fungi that attacked them in their native lands.
Conservationists say the trees, which prevent the growth of indigenous South African vegetation, are too thirsty and are drying up catchment areas in the generally arid country.
